div.p:
Language.TO Å¿peak more of the Original of this People, than that they are deÅ¿cended from the Loins of their great Grandfather Adam, however divers worthy men, have their divers Sentiments; I Å¿hall not pretend; but that they are Originally of one Language is moÅ¿t evident: nor is the admired knowledge of thoÅ¿e Ancients Å¿o admirable, for their ready Å¿peaking more than Twenty Languages which may rationally be Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to have been but one Originally; though Å¿uffering Å¿ome Change, by occaÅ¿ional accidents: We know, the divers pronouncing of the Å¿ame words, without difference in Dialect, may render the Å¿peaker hardly intelligible, to him that writes alike with him; nor do I think the Å¿peech of theÅ¿e Americans Å¿o divers, but that an Indian who is

div.p:
THE WorÅ¿hipful Thomas Mayhew in the Year 1641. having obtained a grant of Martha's Vineyard, Nantuket and Elizabeth IÅ¿les, to make a Settlement; his Son Mr. Thomas Mayhew in the Year 1642. Setled at Martha's Vineyard, with a few other inhabitants, where his Reputation for Piety, his natural gifts, beÅ¿ide the acquired by his Education (having attained no Å¿mall knowledge in the Latin and Greek Tongues, and being not wholly a Stranger
to the Hebrew) Å¿oon OccaÅ¿ioned his call to the MiniÅ¿try among that handful. Not long after, Viz. in the year 1644. God who had Ordained him an EvangeliÅ¿t, for the ConverÅ¿ion of theÅ¿e Gentiles, Å¿tirred him up with an Holy Zeal and ReÅ¿olution, to AÅ¿Å¿ay what SucceÅ¿s he might find in that work; he takes opportunity to inÅ¿inuate, the Love and good will he bore to that People, and Å¿oon finds OccaÅ¿ion to let them no their Deplorable Condition, under Satan; who as he had kept them in Ignorance of thoÅ¿e Bodily and Earthly things, which might render their Lives in this World more happy; Å¿o of thoÅ¿e that related to their Future happineÅ¿s in that to come. And whereas he could not be in hopes of being heard in a more Publick, he Treats them in a more Private way; Å¿ometimes going to Å¿ome particular HouÅ¿es, of PerÅ¿ons whom he eÅ¿teemed moÅ¿t Rational and Well qualified; other while diÅ¿courÅ¿ing with parcular men. The firÅ¿t Indian imbracing the motion of forÅ¿aking their gods, and Praying to the true God, called I a coomes; EÅ¿teemed by the Indians as a contemptible PerÅ¿on among themÅ¿elves; unto this man, God who ordereth all things for His own Glory, gave Å¿o great a meaÅ¿ure of Faith and Confidence in His Power, that he is Å¿oon beyond the fear of Concealing his Contempt of their gods: The Sachems and Powaw's being much inraged, threaten his Life; the Powaw's or Wizzards
told him (a thing Publickly known) that he could not be ignorant, that they could kill Å¿uch as diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed them, Viz. by Witchcraft: he anÅ¿wers for himÅ¿elf before the Sachems, Witches, and a great AÅ¿Å¿embly; acknowledges the god they WorÅ¿hipped had great Power, but Limited, and was SubÅ¿ervient to the God he now had choÅ¿en; therefore although by their means many had Å¿uffered much, and Å¿ome were killed, he deÅ¿piÅ¿ed their power, as being himÅ¿elf a Servant of Him, whoÅ¿e Power overruled all Powers, and ordered all things: The Expecting multitude wait the event, which while they Concluded, to be SickneÅ¿s or Death, the good man remaines wholly Sound to their aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment. Mr. Mayhew makes uÅ¿e of this advantage, is unceÅ¿Å¿ant in his labour, and PromiÅ¿es, Now while they Stumbled in doubt of their own, to Å¿et them in the Right Path; he Å¿pares not his Body by Night nor Day, lodges in their HouÅ¿es, propoÅ¿es Å¿uch things to their ConÅ¿ideration he thinks firÅ¿tly requiÅ¿ite, Å¿olves all their Scruples and Objections; and tells them, they might plainly Å¿ee, it was in good will, for their good, from whom he Expected no reward, that he Å¿uÅ¿tained Å¿o much loÅ¿s of time, and endured wet and cold. It pleaÅ¿ed God to give Å¿uch SucceÅ¿s to theÅ¿e indeavours, that it was not long before he obtained Publick Audience among them; when generally, he Å¿pent more time after Sermon in reaÅ¿oning

This worthy Servant of the Lord continued his painfull Labours among them until the year, 1657. in which time, God pleaÅ¿ed to give Å¿uch SucceÅ¿s to his faithful and unwearied Labour, that many hundred men and women, were added to the Church; Å¿uch who might truely be Å¿aid to be Holy in ConverÅ¿ation, and for knowledge, Å¿uch who needed not to be taught the firÅ¿t Principles of Religion; beÅ¿ide the many hundred of looÅ¿er ProfeÅ¿Å¿ors of which, that Å¿uch worthy ChriÅ¿tians, whoÅ¿e godly Zeal, for Propagating the GoÅ¿pel, to Å¿uch who Å¿at in DarkneÅ¿s and Å¿aw no Light, provoked an holy Emulation, to compaÅ¿s Sea and Land, by their liberal Contributions for ProÅ¿elyting the Heathen, to the Service and WorÅ¿hip of the Lord JeÅ¿us (who yet Survive) might rejoyce, Å¿ince that, God gave a BleÅ¿Å¿ing to, and cauÅ¿ed a Plentiful harveÅ¿t to Succeed their Sowing in theÅ¿e Waters: and that the SucceÅ¿Å¿ors and Children of thoÅ¿e ever to be Honoured deceaÅ¿ed ChriÅ¿tians might rejoyce, that their PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors Religious intent, in giving freely of their Worldly Goods, to advance the Work for Salvation of Souls, was Å¿o far from deminiÅ¿hing their EÅ¿tates; that they thereby left an Inheritance to their Childrens Children.
I Å¿hall give a true Relation of the ProgreÅ¿s, and preÅ¿ent State, of the undertaking, and Gods bleÅ¿Å¿ing following the endeavours of thoÅ¿e he called, for Converting the Indians, on Martha's Vineyard and Adjacent IÅ¿les; by letting the World know, who, and how qualified theÅ¿e were, who were EÅ¿teemed ChriÅ¿tians.

When Å¿uch a Number profeÅ¿Å¿ed the ChriÅ¿tian Religion, as gave OccaÅ¿ion to the Indians in general to EÅ¿teem them a Sect differing from themÅ¿elves, and by the denomination of, Praying men, to Signalize that difference; and that their Number was Å¿uch as to Meet Publickly to WorÅ¿hip God: Å¿uch who forÅ¿ook their HeatheniÅ¿h WorÅ¿hip and Idolatry, profeÅ¿Å¿ing to become ChriÅ¿tians, in the Publick AÅ¿Å¿embly declared the grounds and reaÅ¿ons moving them to imbrace the one, and forÅ¿ake the other way, with their ReÅ¿olution to Pray, to Serve, and indeavour to Obey the true God in JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t; how this ReÅ¿olution was wrought in them, what Temptations had obÅ¿tructed, what ReaÅ¿on, Scripture and Strength from God had incouraged them, and inabled them to retain Å¿uch ReÅ¿olution: how, they had often Prayed to God, and yet been overcome by diÅ¿couragements, and Temptations &c. CloÅ¿ing all with profeÅ¿Å¿ing a ReÅ¿olution, by Gods AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, to Pray to, and Serve Him and Him onely; begging the Prayers of the Congregation to God in

If after Å¿uch Publick ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion, any was obÅ¿erved not to perform the uÅ¿ual WorÅ¿hipping of God, in Praying with their Families, deÅ¿iring a BleÅ¿Å¿ing on their Food, or the like (who yet in their Publick meeting conÅ¿tantly attended) they were Publickly Examined of the Å¿ame: Of which let me give a remarkable inÅ¿tance: One who after his AdmiÅ¿Å¿ion (if I may Å¿o term it) into the Number and Society of the Praying Indians, being preÅ¿ent at a great AÅ¿Å¿embly, after the ExerciÅ¿e, was by him that Preached, informed that it was reported, he had ceaÅ¿ed to Pray, deÅ¿ired him, to let the Congregation know, what grounds and motives occaÅ¿ioned Å¿uch neglect; the man anÅ¿wered, It was true, he had not lately uÅ¿ed Publickly to Pray; yet did Å¿ometimes Pray Privately; that he did not in his judgment diÅ¿approve the Service of God, but acknowledged it to be good; but found himÅ¿elf weak; not able to live up to Rules of that Religion: but when God Å¿hould give him more Å¿trength, he hoped he Å¿hould be again a Praying man.

Thus Mr. Mayhew continued his almoÅ¿t inexpreÅ¿Å¿ible labour and vigilant care for the good of the Indians, whom he juÅ¿tly eÅ¿teemed, his Joy and Crown: and having Å¿een Å¿o great
a BleÅ¿Å¿ing on his faithful indeavours in the making known the Name of his Lord among theÅ¿e Gentiles, with indefatigable pains, expecting no reward, but alone from Him, who Å¿aid; Goe teach all Nations, Lo I am with you: God moved the hearts of Å¿ome Godly ChriÅ¿tians in England, to advance a ConÅ¿iderable Sum for incouraging the propagating, and preaching the GoÅ¿pel to the Indians in New-England: And Å¿eeing the Spirit given to Å¿undry of the Indians, with the gift of PropheÅ¿ying; according to the promiÅ¿e, given by Him who AÅ¿cended, and gave gifts unto men; an able Godly EngliÅ¿h-man, named Peter Foulger, who was imployed in teaching the Youth in Reading, Writing, and the Principles of Religion, by CatechiÅ¿ing; and being well Learned in the Scripture, able to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t them in what might be needful: his Honoured Father, the Governour, well skilled in their Language, and highly honouring the Work for their ConverÅ¿ion; whereby, if in his abÅ¿ence, any difficult matter might happen, they might find Å¿uitable AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance: In the Year 1647. he intended a Å¿hort Voyage for England; but alas! the Ship wherein he took PaÅ¿Å¿age was never heard of; Thus came to an Immature Death, Mr. Mayhew, who was Å¿o affectionately eÅ¿teemed of by the Indians, that many years after, he was Å¿eldom named without Tears.

Mr. Thomas Mayhew, after the loÅ¿s of his Son, as aforeÅ¿aid: Seeing no Å¿uch Salary, probably to be obtained, that might invite a MiniÅ¿ter to imbrace the work among the Indians; and little hopes of finding any of the Spirit of his Son, or Mr. ELIOT, to bear the burthen, attending, and in that day of neceÅ¿Å¿ity to be undergone; without a proÅ¿pect of more than could well be expected, for incouraging to Å¿o in-it-Å¿elf troubleÅ¿ome imploy; and that his onely Son had Å¿pent his Strength, and yet rejoyced in the mid'Å¿t of thoÅ¿e many Aches, Pains and DiÅ¿tempers, contracted by his often lodging in their cold HouÅ¿es, and induring Wet and Cold, in faith of Gods accepting of, and proÅ¿pering him in that, whereunto he could Å¿ee nothing could rationally move him; concludes, that it was Of God, and not of man; he therefore reÅ¿olves to ViÅ¿it and incourage them often; he goes once every Week to Å¿ome of their Plantations; and with the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Godly Indians, who taught and inÅ¿tructed their Neighbours on the Lords Days, perÅ¿waded the Indians of the Gayhead, who many Years, were obÅ¿tinately reÅ¿olved not to admit the Glad-Tydings of the GoÅ¿pel among them (being animated by the Sachims of the Continent) not to imbrace it; Å¿o that now the Indians on the IÅ¿lands of Martha's-Vineyard and Nantuket, might juÅ¿tly

The Indians being thus brought over to the acknowledgment and profeÅ¿Å¿ion of the ChriÅ¿tian Religion; and many of them deÅ¿iring to joyn in Å¿uch Communion, whereby they might injoy the preÅ¿ence of God in all His Ordinances; Mr. Mayhew and Mr. John Cotton (now PaÅ¿tor of the Church of New-Plymouth) who having been Å¿ometime Preacher to the EngliÅ¿h, had attained Å¿ome knowledge in the Indian Tongue, and Preached unto them two Years; being well Satisfied with their Å¿uitable qualifications, after mature ConÅ¿ideration and Advice, concluded to give their Help and AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance thereto; which was happily accompliÅ¿hed, to the good Satisfaction of the EngliÅ¿h Church, and Godly ProfeÅ¿Å¿ors of the IÅ¿land; who by advantage of many years acquaintance with them, had great Experience of their qualifications. Mr. Mayhew by Mr. Cotton's removing from the IÅ¿land, was left alone as to any EngliÅ¿h AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance: But Mr. John Mayhew his grandÅ¿on, being called to Preach to a Å¿mall People; by the urgent and ardent deÅ¿ires of the Indians; and being well skilled in their Language, complyed with them; and once every Week Preached at Å¿ome of their Plantations. His diligence was now to be doubled, eÅ¿pecially after Mr. Mayhew his Grand-fathers Death, in the Year 1681. by reaÅ¿on of certain Heterodox Opinions, likely to take root among them; and being a man of great natural parts, he uÅ¿ed to deÅ¿ire Å¿uch who had imbibed any of thoÅ¿e Principles, to produce their ReaÅ¿ons; as likewiÅ¿e any that deÅ¿ired to be reÅ¿olved in any matter, to give him advantage to reÅ¿olve them in Publick; that others might receive Satisfaction and InÅ¿truction; whereby I believe and know, that they received more Conviction, InÅ¿truction and Satisfaction, than in the ordinary way of Preaching; which alwayes notwithÅ¿tanding preceeded that: inÅ¿omuch that none of thoÅ¿e Erroneous Opinions Å¿pread to the diÅ¿turbance, or unÅ¿ettlement of the Church, nor generallity of profeÅ¿Å¿ors among them: but having finiÅ¿hed what God in His All-wiÅ¿e Providence, Å¿aw good to improve him in; he deceaÅ¿ed in the Year 1688. leaving the Indians (if I might now Å¿o term them)

body.p:

div.p: I have already told my Reader, that the Government of this People was the beÅ¿t of all Governments, Monarchy; and it has been judged not without reaÅ¿on, that a main obÅ¿truction in the progreÅ¿s of the GoÅ¿pel in the American Plantations, was, if not yet is, the jealouÅ¿y the Princes conceived of the InvaÅ¿ion of their Government through the pretences of Religion, and the EclipÅ¿ing their Monarchical Dignity.
